ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I became more confident in my speaking and listening ability, as well as reading comprehension.

Loved the structure of the course content, focusing on learning about arts/culture and social and environmental issues in different spanish speaking countries. I learned more about these topics, expanded my vocabulary and expanded my command of proper grammar.
This class did not increase vocabulary or grammar knowledge significantly, it mostly required independent projects requiring reading of long texts.
This course was great at improving my ability to communicate in Spanish with an emphasis on conversation and novel projects.
Insight into Spanish and Hispanic culture and societal issues while also improving my Spanish knowledge and conversing ability.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The content of each unit was interesting and final projects were not too bad, and I appreciated the opportunity to ask feedback on them before submission. One weakness would be the pretty sizeable workload, especially during the last unit, which stressed me out since we had long readings due while my other classes were also having the final midterms and projects. I also wish the course taught more grammar topics.

Meeting everyday is extremely taxing, especially for grad students. I would suggest the asynchronous day be on Friday to make the course more accessible to graduate students. 

Better use of canvas - it was often unclear what assignments were going to be due in the upcoming week and assignments were often added at the last minute, making planning difficult. Anything due should be listed under "assignments"
Not a lot of time between assigning longer projects and their due dates, basically treated like homework.

The seminar structure of the class and emphasis on conversation and relevant themes was very helpful for improving my Spanish. I also greatly appreciated the focus on projects and participation in tests and quizzes, which helped me to focus on long-term improvement instead of optimizing for tests.
Engaging and promoted emersion into Spanish language and culture. More grammar could potential be covered.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course. It was much better than my Spanish classes during high school, mostly due to it being actually  taught *in* Spanish and having a smaller class size to allow for more opportunities for each student to speak. This was also the most practice I've actually had speaking Spanish, which was definitely helpful. I also learned more about global issues, which was interesting, though sometimes it was a bit difficult to come up with responses, not because I couldn't translate my answer into Spanish, but because it was difficult thinking of an answer. Also important to note, the workload was much higher than what I was expecting.
yes! Feel like I really improved my language skills, I liked the structure of the learning - more conversational and engaging than just learning grammar
Only if filling a language requirement.
The structure is ideal for a language class. The class has no tests or quizzes and focuses instead on conversation and projects.
Yes very good for improving knowledge of Spanish and ability.
